misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because the names and scores arrays are 'parallel', sorting only the scores array will somehow keep each name aligned with its original score. In particular, they think that after calling Arrays.sort on the scores array, the index of the highest score (last index) can be used directly on both arrays to get the correct top student name and score.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, each array is an independent data structure. Calling Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray) reorders only the elements of studentScoresArray; the studentNamesArray remains in its original order. The mapping between a name and its score is positional: if you change the order of one array without applying the exact same reordering to the other, you break that mapping. To keep parallel arrays in sync when sorting, you must either (1) perform a sort that swaps corresponding elements in both arrays simultaneously, or (2) encapsulate name and score into a single object and sort an array/list of those objects. The student’s mental model treats the two arrays as if Java would automatically maintain their parallel relationship during sorting.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: wrong output (correct highest score but incorrect student name, no compile/runtime error)

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when one array in a set of parallel arrays (the scores array) is sorted using a standard library function, the corresponding parallel array (the names array) will automatically rearrange or synchronize itself to maintain the original data pairings (Name[i] maps to Score[i]).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java's `Arrays.sort()` method operates only on the elements of the specified array. It has no mechanism to detect, identify, or modify other variables, including parallel arrays. The act of sorting the scores array breaks the intended parallel relationship because the names array is left untouched. The index of the highest score (now index `N-1`) points to a different student's name in the unsorted names array.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when you sort one array using Arrays.sort(), the corresponding elements in a parallel array will automatically move in sync to maintain the original pairing. Specifically, they believe that after sorting the scores array, the name at index 2 will be the name of the student who got the highest score, without explicitly reordering the names array.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student has misunderstood how Arrays.sort() works. Arrays.sort() operates independently on a single array—it does not and cannot know about parallel arrays. Sorting the scores array rearranges only the scores; the names array remains in its original order. This breaks the index correspondence between parallel arrays. To maintain the relationship, the student would need to either: (1) sort both arrays in coordinated fashion by manually swapping elements, (2) use a custom comparator with a data structure that keeps names and scores together, or (3) create a temporary index array and use it to guide swaps in both arrays.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: The program prints the correct highest score (92) but pairs it with the wrong student name (Charlie instead of Bob). The output reads 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of the expected 'Top student: Bob (92)'.

evidence.code_snippet: // Step 9: After sorting in ascending order, the top student is at the last index

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Assuming parallel arrays stay aligned when sorting only one array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that after sorting the scores array, the indices of the names array will still correspond to the same students, so that the last index in both arrays will refer to the student with the highest score.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are completely independent objects. Calling Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray) reorders only the elements of the scores array, based solely on their numeric values. The names array is never modified, so its order remains as originally entered. This breaks the positional pairing between studentNamesArray[i] and studentScoresArray[i]. After sorting, the highest score (92) moves to the last position in studentScoresArray, but the name at that same index in studentNamesArray is still the original third name (Charlie), not the name associated with that score (Bob). To maintain the relationship, either both arrays must be rearranged together (swapping corresponding elements in both arrays whenever one is moved) or a single array of objects (e.g., a Student class with name and score fields) should be sorted.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel Array Synchronization Failure in Sort
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when `Arrays.sort()` is called on one array (e.g., `studentScoresArray`), Java automatically detects and updates associated parallel arrays (e.g., `studentNamesArray`) to maintain the index correspondence between the elements.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The Java execution model treats arrays as independent data structures. The standard `Arrays.sort()` method only modifies the array it is called upon. It does not possess any mechanism to track or modify separate data structures, even if they were logically parallel prior to the sort. Sorting one parallel array without simultaneously swapping corresponding elements in the other array destroys the established key-value mapping.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: wrong output (The program prints the correct highest score but associates it with the wrong student name because the name array was not sorted/reordered alongside the score array.)

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel Array Desynchronization After Independent Sort
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the scores array in place will somehow maintain the correspondence between names and scores. They think: 'I sort scores in ascending order, so the highest score ends up at the last index. Therefore, the name at the last index must belong to the student with the highest score.'
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not understand that sorting only one of two parallel arrays breaks their correspondence. When Arrays.sort(studentScoresArray) is called, ONLY the scores array is rearranged. The names array remains in its original order. Index-based correspondence is destroyed—the student at index 2 in the names array is still 'Charlie', but the score at index 2 is now 92 (which originally belonged to 'Bob').
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: The program prints 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of 'Top student: Bob (92)'. While the highest score (92) is correctly identified, it is paired with the wrong student name.
